sense.name: establish the truth, validity, or authenticity of something
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[agent] PROVE NP2 NP1[agent] PROVE NP2 (NP3) NP1[agent] PROVE NP3 NP2
sense.examples: Prove it. The theory was proved by the scientists. That theory was proved false. He's so aggressive - it's as if he's always trying to prove something. I have no idea how to prove this mathematically. I haven't been proven guilty yet! They proved him innocent. That just goes to prove what an idiot I am. We proved them wrong! He proved himself a fighter, and we are very proud of him. He really proved himself an idiot during his first term. I will prove to myself that I'm still alive.

sense.name: turn out to be, show a particular result after a period of time
sense.examples: My predictions proved. The operation proved a complete success. The dispute over the song rights proved impossible to resolve. The new treatment has proved to be a disaster. He proved to be the worst singer in the world.

sense.name: show oneself to be competent or worthy
sense.commentary: Is: PROVE ONESELF Syntax Is: NP1 PROVE ONESELF
sense.examples: He had a chance to prove himself. You do have to prove yourself to get ahead. Prove yourself to me.

sense.name: LAW- establish as authentic or genuine
sense.commentary: Note: Related to legal documents, especially testament or will.
sense.examples: The will was proved on 29th January. They might have the will proved. The will proved.

sense.name: COOKING- rise or gain volume in a warm place
sense.commentary: Note: Usually refers to the process of letting dough rise before being baked.
sense.examples: Cover again with a cloth and prove the dough for another hour or so. This pizza dough proved rather quickly.

sense.name: PRINTING ARTS- make a test impression
sense.commentary: Note: Take a test impression of a negative, etching, or type.
